description: From Middle French contresigne. Equivalent to counter- +â€Ž sign.

entries.meaning: (law) A second signature added to a document to affirm the validity of the signature of the first person.
The response to a sign or signal.
examples: Only those who give the countersign may enter the Masonic Lodge.

verbs.description: countersign (third-person singular simple present countersigns, present participle countersigning, simple past and past participle countersigned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To sign on the opposite side of (a document).
(transitive, by extension) To add a second signature to a document, affirming the validity of the signature of another person.
